Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID - Effects of an Extreme Disturbance Event on Genomic Variation and Community Organization of Stream Insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will test hypotheses related to the response of stream organisms (insects) to the extreme, rare flood disturbance of September 2013 in Colorado's Front Range. Genetic and species composition data were collected from these streams prior to the disturbance as part of a previously funded NSF research project. These pre-event data allow the testing of specific evolutionary and ecological hypotheses about how extreme and non-seasonal disturbance acts to selectively remove maladapted genotypes, to modify genetic variation and gene frequencies, and to re-shape biological organization of insect communities through differential species survival and associated transformation of stream food webs. Fourteen headwater streams that span an elevation gradient of over 2,000 meters and that experienced different degrees of flood disturbance will be re-sampled in late Spring 2014.

The extreme flooding in Colorado received national media attention and continues to be a topic of scientific and public discussion, so this study will likely be of broad scientific and public interest. The research represents an unprecedented opportunity to discover broad, new insights into the integrated genetic and ecological response of aquatic insects to discrete, extreme disturbance. Findings from this project will be disseminated not only through professional meetings and journals, but also via the popular press and online venues, in order to help advance public understanding the vulnerability and risks of natural systems to unusually large disturbances of the kind predicted to become increasingly more common under rapid climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The RAPID project has allowed a unique and rare opportunity to study the effects of a high-magnitude (“extreme”) disturbance across multiple stream sites, scaling from genes to ecosystems. The findings from this project will inform our understanding of the dynamics of disturbance on stream communities and their associated ecosystem functions, such as nutrient cycling through stream food webs. Preliminary results suggest that some stream insect species’ body chemistry reflects that of the food that they consume, while others have a more consistent body chemistry. We observed a negative relationship between stream disturbance and the chemical composition of stream insect food resources, although our results were not statistically significant.  We will be completing analyses and updating a broader suite of findings in the coming year, including comparisons in food web structure based on stable isotopes.

 

This project has contributed to the training of one doctoral student at Cornell University who is acquiring fieldwork and analytic research skills in her area of expertise and one post-doctoral associate at Colorado State University, who is acquiring both laboratory and computational skills. Six undergraduates have been engaged in field and labwork. Among the 8 individuals employed by this project, 7 (88%) are women and 2 (25%) are Hispanic, proportions that far exceed the representation of women and Hispanics in STEM fields.  In addition, two individuals are international (from Venezuela and Ecuador), and one student is from Puerto Rico.

 

Additionally, a student sponsored by the Ecological Society of America through their SEEDS program designed to increase diverse representation in the sciences completed an independent project affiliated with this work. All associated researchers with the project are gaining field/lab research, analytical expertise, and experience in writing and dissemination of results. All researchers are also gaining important experience in the management of data and collaborative aspects of a multi-institutional and multi-disciplinary project.

 

We expect our analysis of the impacts of an extreme, non-seasonal flooding event will further our understanding of the impacts of such outlier events for freshwater ecosystem function. Our results will provide insights into stream ecosystem response to global climate change, which may increase the frequency and intensity of regional precipitation extremes in the Rocky Mountain region.
